message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of the right thumb and the shortened and deformed left thumb are consistent with Holt-Oram syndrome. This syndrome is also associated with septal defects, which can cause the wide fixed split in the second heart sound and systolic ejection murmur. Alagille syndrome is associated with congenital heart defects, but not thumb abnormalities. Marfan syndrome is associated with aortic root dilation and dissection, and Williams-Beuren syndrome is associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis, both of which are not consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of the right thumb and the deformed left thumb suggests that Holt-Oram syndrome is the most consistent with the girl’s congenital defects. People with this syndrome can have a wide fixed split in the second heart sound and a medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur. None of the other syndromes listed are known to cause thumb abnormalities or heart defects described in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thumb on one hand and a deformed thumb on the other suggest Holt-Oram syndrome, which is associated with congenital heart defects such as the left-to-right shunt described in this case. All other options have different characteristic features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Holt-Oram syndrome is characterized by heart defects and upper limb anomalies. The absence of a thumb and a shortened and deformed thumb are upper limb anomalies, and the heart defects are consistent with the diagnosis of acyanotic congenital heart disease with left-to-right shunt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Holt-Oram syndrome is a genetic condition that involves upper limb abnormalities and congenital heart defects, which fits with the patient's missing thumb and deformed left thumb as well as the diagnosed acyanotic congenital heart defect with left-to-right shunt. Alagille syndrome involves liver and heart defects, while Marfan syndrome and Williams-Beuren syndrome do not typically involve thumb abnormalities or the specific heart defect mentioned in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thumb and a deformed thumb suggest Holt-Oram syndrome, which is associated with congenital heart defects such as ASD and VSD, which involve left-to-right shunting. The other syndromes listed do not typically involve these specific heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence and deformity of thumbs along with the congenital heart defect suggest a diagnosis of Holt-Oram syndrome. Alagille syndrome is associated with liver and heart defects as well as characteristic facial features. Marfan syndrome is associated with aortic aneurysms and dissections, among other features. Williams-Beuren syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities including supravalvular aortic stenosis, as well as distinctive facial features and developmental disabilities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thumb suggests possible Holt-Oram syndrome, which often presents with upper limb abnormalities and congenital heart defects, specifically atrial septal defects or ventricular septal defects. Alagille syndrome presents with liver involvement and heart defects involving the pulmonary arteries. Marfan syndrome presents with aortic root dilation and dissection, while Williams-Beuren syndrome presents with supravalvular aortic stenosis and hypercalcemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Holt-Oram syndrome is associated with congenital heart defects, along with upper limb abnormalities such as absent or hypoplastic thumbs. Alagille syndrome is associated with liver and bile duct abnormalities. Marfan syndrome is associated with aortic aneurysms and dissections, as well as skeletal and ocular abnormalities. Williams-Beuren syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, as well as distinctive facial features and developmental delays.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a thumb on one hand and a deformed thumb on the other hand is consistent with Holt-Oram syndrome, which is a genetic disorder that can lead to structural heart defects such as atrial septal defect or ventricular septal defect. The wide fixed split in S2 and the medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border are consistent with such a left-to-right shunt. Alagille syndrome would present with peripheral pulmonary stenosis and other features like liver disease, and Marfan syndrome and Williams-Beuren syndrome are also associated with specific heart defects and structural abnormalities, but they are not consistent with the hand anomalies seen in this patient.
